reviewText: Great to know this stuff!
Very informative.

Great beginning. They actually see the brain being self reflective and taking care of itself. They do not conclude that the brain is more than a body, namely that it also involves self reflective mind. They are neural scientists that are not allowed to talk about spirit, although they obviously believe in it.
This information is true and important for people to learn

One of the most important documentaries ever made.  This information puts the solution to mental disorders of all kinds within reach of us all, and all without medication of any kind.  All mental disorders such as PTSD, ADD, ADHD, co-dependency, brain retardation, stroke damage, compulsive behavior, and more, can be managed and nearly eliminated through the brains ability to create new neurons that support normal, healthy thinking.

The talking pig part made me laugh a little (see watch documentary and you will know what I am talking about) I don't regret watching this documentary at all and found watching it very enjoyable. I would definitely recommend watching this documentary if you are considering to watch it, which you most likely are you are reading this review.

--
-Just an Amazon Customer

Astounding, miraculous, spell-binding film about how the brain can adjust and compensate after the body has suffered traumatic injury.  Unbelievable, until you see the actual results.  This is a fascinating, must-watch video.  I knew the human body was amazing, but this is jaw-dropping stuff.  The film is aimed at average, non-medical people.

What an interesting movie, because if it I challenged a women's group I lead to change their brains.  Focus for a week on nothing but positive. I would recommend this book to anyone that may have health issues, and personality issues. This book challenges the watcher that the brain can change.

I watched this documentary in hopes that the issue of what happens to our brains as we age would be addressed. Both my mother and my grandmother died with dementia, which leads me to believe that heredity plays a part in what will happen with me. I will soon be 70 years old and I have already begun to exhibit signs that I am in the early onset of the disease. I am having an extremely hard time in coping with the signs that say I will be a third generation recipient and do not know how to live with the disease.  I would really like to watch more videos which this issue is being addressed and how hopeful the medical professionals are that major advancements are being made to stop and/or delay the deterioration of this debilitating disease of the brain.
Worth a watch to get the basic concept of what Doidge is trying to get across. Of course, the book is always better and goes into more detail.

I chose this video because I live with epilepsy and bipolar disorder. I am constantly seeking new information because I believe there are better ways to treat...even cure through healing the brain. The drugs I take do not completely control my conditions and they come with a multitude of side effects. Although there some slight genetic link on one side of my family in regards to epilepsy, my mother had a very difficult delivery and due to the risks of her very high blood pressure, I was delivered with forceps. I was born in 1968, C-sections were not common, perhaps even not used during that time. My mother said when she first saw me after delivery, my entire face was very bruised, especially the temporal regions and they also had noticeable indentions. I had my first seizure, a grand mal, at age 5 and was hospitalized shortly for testing. A specific brain wave was found to be abnormal in relation to a "normal" brain and I was put on phenobarbital, the only drug available at that time to treat epilepsy. Later, I was switched to Dilantin when that became available. I am left handed. I had difficulty in school under the influence of these drugs. Handwriting was very difficult to learn. However, because I lived in right handed world, I learned to use certain tools like scissors very effectively and I posses a higher degree of ambidexterity than most individuals. Many of my motor tasks are still right brain oriented but some I can easily switch between either hand. At age 11, because no further seizures occurred, medication was discontinued. Needless to say, I went from a struggling C level student to A's and B's. When I entered my late teens/early twenties, I started to have a different form of seizure known as JME. They were partially controlled. I was allergic to many medications or could not withstand the side effects. My brain became kindled and grand mals started to occur with increasing frequency. I was also diagnosed with bi polar disorder in my 20's which could be a mood disorder that developed from the seizures. They shake hands somewhere. Now I am 48. I have been implanted with a VNS device which seems to help mildly with depressive episodes which are season in nature. I do not have full seizure control. I remain on meds for both conditions. I live the healthiest that I am able. I follow a low carb diet but not low enough to be considered ketogenic. I have recently started to use some Buddhist rituals to see if they will help and I go to a therapist who uses DBT as the main treatment from a psychological aspect. In my deepest of being I believe eventually there will be a way to teach our brains how to regulate the biochemistry. I worked in the medical field as a radiation therapist and radiologic technology so I can fully understand the materials I have been able to locate. I think biofeedback and imagination may be the route. I can't have TMS because of the VNS device..which I question if constant stimulation of that nature is the healthiest route. I know I suffer from frequent insomnia that disappears when I turn the device off via the magnet. The lack of sleep contributes to existing health conditions. I'm highly photosensitive. Computer usage must be limited due to the refresh rate of monitors available at this time and I have the best possible screen. I am disabled. I frequently can not drive. I can not swim or bath without some supervision and of course there is SUDEP which has taken the lives of many prematurely. I'm telling my story because this was based more on motor sensory and control than behavioral and biochemical and those like me need these techniques to be looked at on a broader spectrum. If there are any out there who see this or are involved in anyway with these type of innovations that may benefit others with neurological deficits, I beg you to please share anything you think will help. The memory games might override the memory, balance, and word recall that I personally suffer from due to the medications which we know alter cellular structure. I will be attempting to contact the professionals in this video in hopes they may be able to offer some methods in which a broader spectrum of those in need can benefit from and I was amazed by the results. From my deepest convictions come the gratitude for the work you have done and are doing. I believe you are on the cusp of even more phenomenal discoveries which can be extended to humanity. I wanted to add that music might be interesting to use with these treatments because it's ability to stimulate the entire brain. Just a thought.

Respectfully, Julie Gianferrara.

This film provides a great introduction to the concept and reality of neuroplasticity. This involves the brain's ability to rewire itself so that significant healing can take place.  People who have suffered strokes, traumatic brain injuries, PTSD, and brain damage prior to (or after) birth can greatly benefit from watching this with loved ones. Neuroplasticity may also prove helpful to those with basic learning disabilities, serious pain issues -- and many other hard-to-solve medical or cognitive problems.
It's amazing what we are learning about the human body.
Some fascinating case studies here. Makes me wonder about the possible implications for mental illness and simply character. Can I become happier and more optimistic with intensive brain training?

This was a very interesting movie. I felt like it was very informative on different ideas on how the brain functions and even if you don't understand most things about the brain, it is open enough that you get the general idea. Would recommend even if you are just vaguely interested.
I loved the book "The Brain that Changes Itself" and the new Norman Doigde's book "The Brain Way of Healing". Watching a show focused on his first book was very enjoyable.

I found this really interesting, thought-provoking, and encouraging. The growing knowledge about neural plasticity seems like it might be opening up a brave new world or all kinds of things - how to address the needs of individuals with "learning disabilities," people who have lost limbs, use of  artificial limbs, and who knows what else. Maybe it'll be a way to make normal people smarter, more creative, and with better memories. I recommended this film to a young family member who is considering different fields in the health care sector.
Interesting information

This is a very interesting documentary. I have experienced the plasticity of the brain first hand as I had a stroke a few years ago and had to re-learn many things, using new parts of the brain that weren't affected by the stroke. I was impressed by some of the techniques that were shown in this film, and happy to see that there are doctors who have found a way to improve the function of even damaged brains.
This film may not hold the attention of everyone, but I find it very informative and educational. I consider my time watching this film to be well spent.

After a century or so of brain-damage-is-permanent dogma, this is important news to get out.

Over the last thirty years, I've observed my brain changing itself, coming back from a scalpel-slip that locked me into a world where I could remember nothing for more than ten minutes. My neurologist told me to expect no improvement, and my company offered to lavishly retire me at age 32. To me, both options sounded dreadful. (These days, I'd have the sense to take the retirement, then get a job, duh!)

If you met me today, you might be able to trip me up by telling me your name and then immediately asking me what your name is, or by asking me to remember directions that involve two or more turns, but the only other obvious clue is that I ALWAYS carry a 3x5 index card in my pocket, and write on it constantly. Unfortunately, I still come across as an annoying know-it-all.
I learned a lot. It was interesting and to the point.

Fascinating and true!  Our brains can make the impossible possible.  In every day language you will learn what "neuroplasticity" is. In this mind-changing documentary with anecdotal, jaw dropping stories of how lives are transformed..  Norman Doidge, M.D., provides an introduction to both the scientists championing neuroplasticity and the people whose lives transformed.  From a blind from birth professor who can see using a device on his tongue  to the remarkable case of a woman born with half a brain that rewired itself to work as a whole, The Brain That Changes Itself can change the way we look at who we are and what is possible..

Over the years I have read several articles on neuroplasticity and experienced it first hand after a significant accident. I am a researcher and experienced decreased cognitive functions. I retrained my brain with Luminosity and took courses with Coursera to reignite my cognitive function.  The Brain that Changes Itself is a documentary that reaffirmed my understanding and belief in neuroplasticity. People who have experienced decreased cognitive functions such as Traumatic Brain Injury from accidents, and caregivers should view The Brain that Changes Itself to understand neuroplasticity and its possibilities.

What we think actually changes our brain!  Its implication is profound.  Culture can change the ability of the people.

This reminded me of a Bible verse: " .. whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is right, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is admirable  if anything is excellent or praiseworthy  think on these things."  Philippians 4:8.
Not as detailed as the book. But a great introduction. The book is fantastic! I read it years ago, and it changed how I look at my own capacity to learn and change my own behavior patterns.
Neuroplasticity fascinates me. This documentary gives a glimpse at the developments in treating various brain traumas.
Well presented and eye opening!
Interesting
Excellent and enlightening.  And encouraging.

Could not be any more excited about the implications this provides for human life and the transformation we'll experience as a result of their dedication. This spells out that the ultimate Limitless (movie) pill, is within the mind itself. Great job!
Very informative. I couldn't tell how current it actually was.
Very good presentation, could have have longer for more details.

Life changing for me. I always knew that there was a way to change the way you think, feel, produce, act, develop, and perform. This informative documentary is only the beginning for those suffering from all maladies that extend from the brain. Help has arrived. Excited for this new line of drug therapy without the drugs. Hope for humanity. I love all these videos and the pioneering work of doctors and researchers willing to think outside the box.

Wonderfully presented with factual information.  To know that I can do about anything that I wish to do mentally, is amazing.  I'll never say, I can't do this or that because with my brain's plasticity, I can learn about anything if I take the time to learn it.  So, I am taking charge of my brain and continuing to learn because an active brain is a healthy brain.  A healthy brain means a healthy body, too.  Because, one can't sit around and learn how to do things.  You need to use your body to get up and learn things such as dancing, yoga, and stretching exercises.
Very good
Informative - good information and presented in a clear manner.
Great documentary! Anyone interested should watch
Informative
Incredible, true research- fascinating.
Very informative.  Some of the info is older but still good .  Some people may not be aware of it.  However. loved the documentary.  More of the same please
So interesting! I really enjoyed watching this and I'll probably watch it again.
Loved it.
Fascinating!!
Fascinating

Loved the book. The documentary cannot go into the same depth but is a great companion to the book or a good primer if you haven't read the book. I highly recommend both. Covers many areas of brain plasticity and practical application, such as rewiring the brain to recover from stroke,

At first I objected to the notion that the concept of neuroplasticity throughout life was new.  Doidge apparently had been well aware of the brain properties that I learned about as neuroplasticity in grad school in the fifties.  The big difference that came later that he dealt with was making good theoretical and therapeutic use of that knowledge.  I actually learned from the movie even from work with which I was quite familiar. I gained great respect for Doidges treatment of the info and appreciate what he taught me in this film.
Very good documentary. There is so much that we don't know about the brain and this study shows we are learning more all the time.
Very interesting.

This documentary was a joy to watch, and inspirational. I hope these scientists and researchers will continue to explore our brains and how to help people who have lost functioning due to illness, trauma or injuries. The brain is indeed plastic, and this film shows just how powerful our brains can rewire.
Probably an OK video but I didn't learn anything new or anything that I could apply.
Loved it and I'm not even a science geek!  Our Brain is magnificent and I thank the Universe we have hope to change for the better when it's not working very well.
Informative and educational
Excellent and fascinating documentary.

Like all Science, it is both important to be conservative and skeptical but also adventurous as long as the difference is clearly understood nd recognized.  This documentary may straddle that line a bit but it is understandable coming from proponents since the entire concept of Neuroplasty is both new and exceptionally important. Additionally those people suffering in situations or from conditions where Neuroplasty contains Hope, an intensely useful condition for good health and recovery from ill health, will find this very important and helpful since many doctors elect to not explain conditions or prospects beyond the merely cursory. Recommended!

Great documentary! I agree that we can change our brain and refused to accept the teaching that we're born the way we are. Life would seem so pointless that way... So great to see science finally supporting my personal view and to also see how so many are benefitting medically from this deviation from traditionally accepted science.
Excellent
Excellent information. My mother's memory is impaired and I will consider neuroplasticity for her after seeing it.
Great learning
Great to reinforce the things that have I have been reading as well.
enjoyed it
Inspiring news about the brain and our capacity to learn!  This came out in 2008 so I would love to see more current news on the topic
Interesting
Quite interesting and enjoyable.  Wished they had included more info on the device being used.
Easily understandable by nonscientists.  Interesting
Not too brainy but interesting
Very interesting.
Was ok
I had already read the book and found this film to be very interesting and worthwhile.  It gave me more insight into the amazing power of the human brain.
Paradigm shift worth knowing and considering in ones personal development.
Interesting but would have liked to see more practical ways to do what they were describing
Very informative.
Eye Opening, Scientific, Real World Studies, Entertaining and Interesting... Great job of showing in depth results from an understandable perspective...
Very informative even from a physician standpoint

Without doubt, this cogent documentary includes a balanced cast of brain research pioneers whose discoveries and practical implementation stories of success awaken awe and hope.  No one who is concerned about education, rehabilitation, pain management, slowing memory loss, and enrichment of intellect will question their investment of 55 minutes of their life. Touche'
Interesting

Wonderful documentary on how the brain tries to compensate for injury. I have recommend it to people I know who have suffered stroke. Since cerebral vascular accidents have run in my family, this gives me hope that I may have a good future, if I ever suffer a stroke. Excellent insights into other brain functions and conditions, too.
Great film; very informative
Its Ok. Could be more in depth than what was reported.
The movie is great - particularly if you've already read the book.

Fascinating documentary with riveting anecdotes of people whose lives were  dramatically improved when their brains changed through different techniques. Easy to follow.  This film makes the audience want to cheer right along with the folks portrayed who  experience significant improvements in their quality of life.
As someone who had a brain and neck injury I know it is very much true ,we disabled do adapt.
Very informative

Very interesting and well explained cases showing neural plasticity and the fact our brains are not static hardware. It did bother me they took this to mean our brains are not like computers. The fact our brain physically changes in reaction to thought processes can be likened to software which interacts with mechanical tools which rearrange hardware to be more efficient for the specific softwares purpose. In other words it shows brains to be complex self-modifying computers.

Overall this point wasn't key to learning something from this presentation. Very interesting stuff that'll make you wonder if we'll soon be creating new senses with technology.
Awesome
Would recommend everyone see this. The brain is so great it can heal itself.  New methods are being tried successfully to overcome disabilities.  There is hope out there people!
Informative and educative!
Very interesting and insightful.  Shows you that the limitations of humans may not be as limited as once thought.
Very informative.
Great movie about brain plasticity.
Great!

Simply stunningly clinical stories. I thought that knew the current limits of brain plasticity, but wow!
Makes you wonder about so much more regarding our brains ....
Recent discoveries that should be astounding to 99% of the audience and that offer some hope for many cognitive disorders.
Very good Movie
Very impressed with the information contained in this documentary. Pleased to have been informed.
Well done. Fascinating!
Excellent & very helpful regarding brain Neuroplasticity. A must watch for anyone that has suffered a head or brain injury.
Awesome
Very informative
Loved it!!
It was a good companion to the book.
Most hopeful and inspiring
Great reading for learning how the brain functions
Excellent, I learned so much.
Extremely interesting data and very helpful.
Informative
Do not let these "experts" fool you.  Read real evidence-based research on the mechanics of nature and nurture.
Informative. Kind of boring. Worth watching, could've been better.
Insightful and interesting.
Self improvement and maintain your brain at any age
Fascinating information! Loved it and have told a lot of friends and family to watch it!
Very hopeful news for those with brain injuries and for those of us trying to hide from alzheimers.
Excellent introduction to brain plasticity. Watch this video and then read books about each of the persons featured, especially Paul Bach-y-Rita and V. S.  Ramachandran.

What a great documentary on neuroplasticity.  It has always held my interest and it was curious to see the research behind the method and how neuroplasticity is being used today to help those recover from illness or accidents and also how a layman may be able to enhance their cognitive function.
Very interesting and well informed speakers.
I felt so positive watching this! The creativity and imagination of humans is boundless. We find new ways to enhance each others lives daily. A great movie!

Revolutionary thought about the way the brain works. However, jumping about from the physical to the mental aspects made it a little difficult to keep interest. And there was no investigation into how chemicals/drugs could enhance neuroplasticity.

Reinforces my upbringing as a Christian Scientist (no longer practicing but after watching this should be!), also basis of some martial arts. Worked as an Occupational Therapist for over 35 years and half of what I did for therapy for stroke and TBI would be changed now with this information as so many advances have been made since then. Implications here for future makers of video games, and even  drug rehab in the right hands. The old adage "be careful of what you wish for" can also apply.
This documentary changed how I think of the brain. Some simply incredible work being done by some very smart people. Give it a watch!

Everybody should watch this - the implications for those with TBI's etc are incredible, but not only that, just seeing what the brain is capable of under these extreme conditions should really give you pause for what is possible in your own life with learning and application. I really enjoyed this and have also read Dr. Norman Doidge's books. I wish they had included the names of the featured neuroplasticians in the credits as I wanted to look them up and did not have time to watch it again.
This shows the brain is anti-entropic.

It's like seeing a magic show, but there are no tricks--it's all in the power of our own brains!  I am personally just fascinated by this topic and seeing another video about it provides more info.
V.S. Ramachandran has a great interview on Impact Theory that goes into more details about some of these ideas.  With all that has been discovered, it's just incredible to think of what else remains to be discovered!

This documentary and its ideas helped me connect the dots on several levels and understand myself and others through a fairly radical new lens of understanding.  I would be surprised if it did not change your thinking about how our brains work. It, well, blew my mind.
